name: Anonymous
com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

Modern DNA seems to suggest Anglos mixed with native Britons. But this does not sound peaceful, as Briton culture was completely eradicated and pushed west. Nothing seems to have been incorporated into Anglo culture from Romano British living among them. No place names, language, customs or even clothes.

Yet we know Romano British culture was strong, incredibly versed in written Latin and thriving with Christianity (much to the distaste of the visiting preachers from Rome), and even trading with Byzantium right up until the Anglo's appear. Could it be there were multiple Anglo migrations during 400 - 700AD, with eventual takeover in between? The only thing that would contest this I think would be the fact Romano British culture just doesn't survive in England at all afterwards (no sign of integration).

The thought of all the (early) human experiences lost to prehistory makes my head spin. I can't imagine what it would be like to live back then, but I can't help but put together these vague associative constructs. Fear and brutality mixed with childhood lucidity. Animal smells and the touch of wood on callused hands. Rhythmic movement under an unpolluted sky.
I know it's about as real as some warped bucolic fantasy, but there is a feeling behind it that has this strange solid quality. Like the image of a millenia-old vampire dining on silver plates, in candlelight, inside a dirty rundown 21st century building amidst empty plastic bottles, used up spray cans, fast fashion rags and used condoms.

At the advent of the semiconductor it would be far fetched to assume computers would reach the current level of complexity, it depended on how much we could miniaturize transistors and keep down costs which was an unknown. However with DNA we have naturally evolved life as existing examples of the level of complexity it can reach.

We simply need to "reverse engineer" life, first single celled organisms, like algae to produce alcohol for industrial purposes or something along those lines. Then multicellular life, it may even be possible to build it from scratch, study how embryos form, figure out a way to allow the vagus nerve to take a shorter route, delete the appendix.

We may not even need to rely on familiar natural processes, we may be able to "3d print" an entire organism by depositing cells where we want and chemically programming them to form blood vessels, nerves and different tissues. Or if nanotechnology advances to a certain point create a form of life that uses processes besides carbon based chemistry.

Within our lifetimes, perhaps not, but there are so many possibilities. I for one certainly intend to explore the option of transferring the neurons responsible for my consciousness to a machine that will allow me superior abilities and eternal life.

>wouldn't it also follow that John the Baptist was also potential heir to the throne as a close relative Jesus?
No because the prophecy in Micah 5:2 is about Bethlehem in particular, saying that the Redeemer shall be born there. So anyone not born in Bethlehem wouldn't be a suspect in Herod's eyes, and that's why he only killed those males under 2 years old who lived in the vicinity of that town.

>And if so, did that play a role in the household of Herod pushing to have him killed?
The Herod mentioned above is Herod the Great, who died in 4 BC. The Herod who had John the Baptist killed was Herod the Tetrarch, also known as Herod Antipas, who was one of the heirs of the former Herod. They were part of the same dynasty, and indeed father and son, but not the same person. Furthermore, the reason why John the Baptist was imprisoned was because he had called out Herod about marrying the wife of his own brother. The reason why John the Baptist was subsequently killed was because Herod had promised to grant any request at a party, and Herodias requested that John the Baptist's head be brought in on a platter, and Herod was too afraid to go back on his word in front of his party guests to refuse. This is mentioned in Matthew 14.
